Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: In and Around Theory X
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the last generation the four-dimensional classical self-dual Yang-Mills equations and their dimensional reductions have had profound consequences for algebraic geometry, differential geometry, low-dimensional topology, integrable systems, and nonlinear PDE. Now a family of six-dimensional quantum field theories is emerging as an object of acute mathematical interest. This Focused Research Group brings together researchers working in diverse parts of mathematics and physics to study these theories. They originally arose as limits of string theories and are usually called 'superconformal (2,0)-theories' to call attention to their symmetries. The simpler appellation 'Theory X' emphasizes how little is known. The projects undertaken here have two overall goals. First, we will make inroads on the structure of Theory X by applying the detailed and profound mathematical understanding of topological and conformal quantum field theories obtained over the past 25 years. Second, we will use expected properties of Theory X and its compactifications to lower dimensions to deduce new conjectures and new organizing principles in geometric representation theory. The rapidly developing web of interactions between the six-dimensional quantum Theory X and a host of central topics in twenty-first century geometry, topology, and geometric representation theory indicates that we are seeing the beginnings of a new revolution, one in which Theory X plays the dominant physical role. Progress towards unraveling its structure and its consequences will have broad ramifications.

Physics has long fueled developments in mathematics, and the past 30 years have been a particularly fruitful period. The depth of mathematics which enters fundamental physical theories has steadily intensified, and at the same time the structure and predictions of these theories have had increasingly profound impacts on mathematics. This project is one of many efforts to mine this intellectually fertile mix of ideas. Our pursuit of Theory X will inevitably illuminate a much broader circle of ideas and contribute to the mathematical understanding of contemporary physics. The work of past generations at the mathematics-physics interface fuels the modern world: our computers, GPS systems, transportation, sophisticated medical tools, and much more owe their existence to basic research in this area which stretches back well over a century. While we cannot predict how current basic research will impact the future, we can say with certainty that the effect will be far-reaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Theory X" is the name that our research group chose for a theoretical model quantum theory discovered by physicists in the 1990's (and called the "six-dimensional (2,0) theory"). It is unrealistic for our universe for three different reasons -- its space-time has six, and not four dimensions; it is scale-invariant, whereas distance matters greatly in real physics; and it carries an exotic type of internal symmetries (supersymmetry) which is not known to exist in nature, despite vigorous search for it.

However, these deadly flaws become mathematical virtues for the theoretical study of general features of quantum physics: a reduction procedure can be used to produce quantum theories in a space-time of 4, 3 and even 2 dimensions; scale-invariance and super-symmetry are jointly responsible for an enhanced collection of symmetries, which make features of the lower-dimensional theories computable. Ample evidence has emerged that the restuling structures, which can be analysed by methods of topology (theory of shape), algebraic geometry (the study of spaces described by solutions to algebraic equations) and, most recently, representation theory (the study of symmetries of Euclidean space, and its higher-dimensional generalisations). In fact, there result predictions of dualities between quantum theories in 2 and in 4 dimensions, and of pairs of distinct 3-dimensional theories (note: 6 = 2+4 = 3+3).

Remarkably, these quantum theories in lower dimension are all "gauge theories" -- theories built from their own internal symmetries -- just like the standard model of particle physics. In fact, in 4 dimensions they are a close cousin of the standard model, with some additional supersymmetry. Again, what makes them unphysical makes them mathematically very tractable, and these variant standard models were discovered (by Kapustin and Witten) in the early 2000's to embody a long-conjectured duality between different groups of symmetries, known in number theory and geometry as the Langlands program. These dualities in turn, not all of them mathematically verified, would have a remarkable array of consequences in number theory and algebraic geometry, ranging from complex algebraic identities to strucural isomorphisms of abstract objects ("D-modules versus local systems" is one example).

The final ingredients are the boundary and defect structures in a quantum theory. Boundary structures are easier to describe: the vibrations of a string depend on whether its ends are tied or loose; water waves in a long channel will change according to whether the gates are closed or open to the sea. (In classical physics, these are called boundary conditions, but for quantum theory 'boundary structure' is a better term). Defects are more the stuff of science fiction (the gravitational filaments in Star Trek); no macroscopic ones are known in real physics, but the scale-invariant Theory X is rich in them. Their behaviour is goverend by algebraic structures which have become understood only in the last decade. Again, the rich symmetries on Theory X allow us to study them by easier algebraic methods as opposed to more difficult analytic methods. 

This formed the background of our research program, and the researchers then investigated different branches of the vast tree of dualities.

Teleman studied a reduction to 3 dimensions of Theory X and its boundary structures. He found those in a 2-dimensional quantum field theory, the Gromov-Witten theory (subject of interest to algebraic geometers over the past decades). This spun off into an independent NSF-funded research project ('gauge theory and mirror symmetry', in progress). A special case was a surprising result with Freed (UT Austin) describing representations of loop groups (symmetries related to quantum theory in 2 dimensions) by matrix factorisations (an ingredient in the study of Gromov-Witten theory.  Finally, Teleman and Freed found that some troubling ambiguities of Theory X (multi-valuedness of the partition function) were in fact controlled by a topological quantum field theory in 7 dimensions. This phenomenon was already familiar in low-dimensional physics (with examples coming from condensed matter) and Freed and Teleman developed a model of Relative Field Theories explaining the general phenomenon.

Teleman (with Freed and assistance from physics colleagues) co-organised a workshop at the Aspen Physics Center, on the topic of boundary and defect structures inspired by Theory X. 

Frenkel focused on dualities derived from Theory X. With Gukov and Teschner, he generalized a corresponence (originally conjectured by physicists) between surface defects in 4 dimensions and the separation of variables in a 2-dimensional quantum theory (related to loop groups). There turned out to be two types of surface defects, related by a low-energy duality. In the correspondence with 2 dimensions, this became a well-known separation of variables between the loop group theory and another well-known Liouville theory. They connected this to a higher-dimensional duality, between systems of M5 and M2 defects in M-theory, a conjectural "mother theory" for all known instances of string theory.
